awd_titl_txt: BD Hubs: MIDWEST: SEEDCorn: Sustainable Enabling Environment for Data Collaboration
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalyzed by the NSF Big Data Hub program, the Universities of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, North Dakota, and Iowa State University have created a flexible regional Midwest Big Data Hub (MBDH), with a network of diverse and committed regional supporting partners (including colleges, universities, and libraries; non-profit organizations; industry; city, state and federal government organizations who bring data projects from multiple private, public, and government sources and funding agencies). The NSF-funded SEEDCorn project will be the foundational project to energize the activities of MBDH, leveraging partner activities and resources, coordinating existing projects, initiating 20-30 new public-private partnerships, sharing best practices and data policies, starting pilots, and helping to acquire funding. The result of SEEDCorn will be a sustainable hub of Big Data activities across the region and across the nation that enable research communities to better tackle complex science, engineering, and societal challenges, that support competitiveness of US industry, and that enable decision makers to make more informed decisions on topics ranging from public policy to economic development.

The MBDH is focusing on specific strengths and themes of importance to the Midwest across three sectors: Society (including smart cities and communities, network science, business analytics), Natural & Built World (including food, energy, water, digital agriculture, transportation, advanced manufacturing), and Healthcare and Biomedical Research (which spans patient care to genomics). Integrative "rings" connect all spokes and will be organized around themes of specific MBDH strengths, including (a) Data Science, where computational and statistical approaches can be developed and integrated with domain knowledge and societal considerations that support the underlying needs of "data to knowledge," (b) services, infrastructure, and tools needed to collect, store, link, serve, and analyze complex data collections, to support pilot projects, and ultimately provide production-level data services across the hub, and (c) educational activities needed to advance the knowledge base and train a new generation of data science-enabled specialists and a more general workforce in the practice and use of data science and services. 

Further information on the project can be found at http://midwestbigdatahub.org.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
A. Intellectual merit and broader impacts

Large amounts of data are generated and collected in modern science, industry, government, and society by a wide range of activities, including the manufacturing and transportation industries, communications systems, agriculture, medicine and medical research, and large-scale scientific research. 

The Big Data Innovation Hubs program was established by the National Science Foundation (NSF) in 2015 to encourage collaboration among academic researchers, local and regional government agencies, industry, and local communities, specifically around the creation, sharing, and use of large collections of data. The Midwest Big Data Hub (MBDH) serves this role across a 12-state region.* The MBDH focuses on five theme areas that are priorities for research, development, and commerce in the Midwest: agriculture; water quality; materials and manufacturing; health and biomedicine; and smart, connected, and resilient communities. The MBDH also focuses on topics that are relevant to each of these themes, such as data science education and workforce development, the computing infrastructure necessary for modern science, and cybersecurity.

In its first four years, the MBDH engaged in a variety of activities to stimulate research, education, and innovation in the Midwest, in order to advance knowledge in data science, and to benefit the stakeholder community and society at large. The MBDH and its partner institutions offered several hands-on data science education and training events, focused on students and early-career professionals, to build the level of knowledge and skills in the region. Through technical workshops and individual engagements, the Hub helped researchers and practitioners from a range of institutions make connections that led to new activities around its theme areas. These brought in new funding and resources to the region from both federal agencies and industry. The Hub held annual stakeholder community meetings to share information and develop plans for future activities.

*Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, South Dakota, and Wisconsin

 

B. Publications and other products

The MBDH website (http://midwestbigdatahub.org/) provides the public with an archive of information from its past activities, many of which are educational, including from its annual All-Hands Meetings and from technical workshops. 

 

A. Intellectual merit and broader impacts

Large amounts of data are generated and collected in modern science, industry, government, and society by a wide range of activities, including the manufacturing and transportation industries, communications systems, agriculture, medicine and medical research, and large-scale scientific research. 

 

The Big Data Innovation Hubs program was established by the National Science Foundation (NSF) in 2015 to encourage collaboration among academic researchers, local and regional government agencies, industry, and local communities, specifically around the creation, sharing, and use of large collections of data. The Midwest Big Data Hub (MBDH) serves this role across a 12-state region.* The MBDH focuses on five theme areas that are priorities for research, development, and commerce in the Midwest: agriculture; water quality; materials and manufacturing; health and biomedicine; and smart, connected, and resilient communities. The MBDH also focuses on topics that are relevant to each of these themes, such as data science education and workforce development, the computing infrastructure necessary for modern science, and cybersecurity.

 

In its first four years, the MBDH engaged in a variety of activities to stimulate research, education, and innovation in the Midwest, in order to advance knowledge in data science, and to benefit the stakeholder community and society at large. The MBDH and its partner institutions offered several hands-on data science education and training events, focused on students and early-career professionals, to build the level of knowledge and skills in the region. Through technical workshops and individual engagements, the Hub helped researchers and practitioners from a range of institutions make connections that led to new activities around its theme areas. These brought in new funding and resources to the region from both federal agencies and industry. The Hub held annual stakeholder community meetings to share information and develop plans for future activities.

 

   

*Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, South Dakota, and Wisconsin

 

B. Publications and other products

The MBDH website (http://midwestbigdatahub.org/) provides the public with an archive of information from its past activities, many of which are educational, including from its annual All-Hands Meetings and from technical workshops. 

 

C. Other relevant information 

The MBDH and the three other regional Big Data Hubs received additional funding in 2019 to continue their current activities and growth. In its second phase, the Midwest Hub has strengthened its focus on water quality as a priority area. There are many researchers within the Midwest region focused on exploring connections between data science and water quality, especially around the Great Lakes, the Mississippi River, and other water resources that are critical to health, agriculture, and the economy. Our emphasis on advanced materials research and manufacturing has also increased, to address the growth of next-generation manufacturing initiatives within the region.

 


Last Modified: 12/18/2019
Modified by: William D Gropp

A. Intellectual merit and broader impacts
 
Large amounts of data are generated and collected in modern science, industry, government, and society by a wide range of activities, including the manufacturing and transportation industries, communications systems, agriculture, medicine and medical research, and large-scale scientific research. 
 
 
 
The Big Data Innovation Hubs program was established by the National Science Foundation (NSF) in 2015 to encourage collaboration among academic researchers, local and regional government agencies, industry, and local communities, specifically around the creation, sharing, and use of large collections of data. The Midwest Big Data Hub (MBDH) serves this role across a 12-state region.* The MBDH focuses on five theme areas that are priorities for research, development, and commerce in the Midwest: agriculture; water quality; materials and manufacturing; health and biomedicine; and smart, connected, and resilient communities. The MBDH also focuses on topics that are relevant to each of these themes, such as data science education and workforce development, the computing infrastructure necessary for modern science, and cybersecurity.
 
 
 
In its first four years, the MBDH engaged in a variety of activities to stimulate research, education, and innovation in the Midwest, in order to advance knowledge in data science, and to benefit the stakeholder community and society at large. The MBDH and its partner institutions offered several hands-on data science education and training events, focused on students and early-career professionals, to build the level of knowledge and skills in the region. The Hub held annual stakeholder community meetings to share information and develop plans for future activities.
 
 
 
    
 
*Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, South Dakota, and Wisconsin

The MBDH website (http://midwestbigdatahub.org/) provides the public with an archive of information from its past activities, many of which are educational, including from its annual All-Hands Meetings and from technical workshops.

The MBDH and the three other regional Big Data Hubs received additional funding in 2019 to continue their current activities and growth. Our emphasis on advanced materials research and manufacturing has also increased, to address the growth of next-generation manufacturing initiatives within the region.
